text:
I plan to, but at the moment it’s just one at a time.
I have a neural net doing price predications and scalp based on that.
Working quite well at the moment but need to cash out when things go wrong which is why I need this.
I tried this equation out, am I right in saying it calculates a ‘win / no bet’ result eg. no loss but only one result gives a profit?
I’m hoping for something like: layAmount = (backOdds / layOdds) * backAmount Or backAmount = (layOdds / backOdds) * layAmount
Which gives a arbitrage bet where you generate a profit on either side.
How’s your strategy working?

text:
Oh that's an interesting project! Mine is less interesting, I'm building a mobile app to assist people improving their trading and the cashout feature is just because betfair mandates that if you're building an app for customers the app must allow bet placement.

The equation is meant to hedge your position in the market so effectively spreading the profit/loss across all selections. The thing is, the equation is applied at runner level so you'd need to apply to all runners you have bets on and aggregate the PL to get the market PL

elements.text:
Oh that's an interesting project! Mine is less interesting, I'm building a mobile app to assist people improving their trading and the cashout feature is just because betfair mandates that if you're building an app for customers the app must allow bet placement.

The equation is meant to hedge your position in the market so effectively spreading the profit/loss across all selections. The thing is, the equation is applied at runner level so you'd need to apply to all runners you have bets on and aggregate the PL to get the market PL

text:
to calculate the selection profit (if you cashed out) you can use this:
For hedging with a back: profit = layProfit + hedgeStake - backAmount

for lay: profit = layProfit - hedgeStake + backAmount

elements.text:
to calculate the selection profit (if you cashed out) you can use this:
For hedging with a back: profit = layProfit + hedgeStake - backAmount

for lay: profit = layProfit - hedgeStake + backAmount

text: the layProfit = layReturn - layLiability

elements.text: the layProfit = layReturn - layLiability

text: again this is to be applied PER SELECTION (traded) and then you aggregate to get the market picture

elements.text: again this is to be applied PER SELECTION (traded) and then you aggregate to get the market picture

text: With all this talk of milliseconds and latency, has anyone done a study of this in detail? I mean you will surely get different results due to thread/process scheduling times unless you are running things such that you have a process single connection using a blocking socket connection configured such that the process runs on a specific processor? I mean I know that people have multiple processors and cores etc but everything is subject to OS scheduling. I mean yesterday I was getting over 100ms delays (close to 200ms at one point) on the GPS feed as calculated from the FEED time (not the 'pt'). I had Firefox running too and once I closed that down the delay dropped to a steady 70ms. I imagine that some of the people here making larger profits are running setups that have minimal lag. Anyone looked at this kind of thing in depth, or can point out any flaw in my thinking on this matter?

text: Yeah right now I am and I completely understand why you are taking the piss. It is complicated, I basically wrote a linux version of Betangel and I gutted that to create a render for the GPS feed displaying all sorts of diagnostics and stuff as well as manual ladders etc. Now that I have some strats that are seemingly working I am in the process of getting those as headless node.js apps that I will run on a server but it is a work in progress

text: To answer your question, yes I've studied latency a lot

elements.text: To answer your question, yes I've studied latency a lot

text: And to get the lowest latency do you need to assign applications to specific cores/processors or can you get the same results using max (min) nice level or similar?

elements.text: And to get the lowest latency do you need to assign applications to specific cores/processors or can you get the same results using max (min) nice level or similar?

text: I can't speak for Python or Linux, but I can run my entire system inside a VM on my laptop, with over 50 threads running across all applications, but because most are idle at any time, it still takes less than a millisecond to pass from one thread to another. I see no reason why this wouldn't be the case for Linux, and Python (to a point). The key is not to do anything time intensive in the chain from price to calculation to betting

elements.text: I can't speak for Python or Linux, but I can run my entire system inside a VM on my laptop, with over 50 threads running across all applications, but because most are idle at any time, it still takes less than a millisecond to pass from one thread to another. I see no reason why this wouldn't be the case for Linux, and Python (to a point). The key is not to do anything time intensive in the chain from price to calculation to betting

text: I don't pin to cores but you could if you wanted to. I don't use nice either

elements.text: I don't pin to cores but you could if you wanted to. I don't use nice either

text: If you really care about scheduling you can run your bet execution thread with a busy loop

elements.text: If you really care about scheduling you can run your bet execution thread with a busy loop

text: I find pthread condition variables work fine

elements.text: I find pthread condition variables work fine

text: OS's these days are pretty efficient at scheduling threads that need to do work, with most threads on any machine idle most of the time

elements.text: OS's these days are pretty efficient at scheduling threads that need to do work, with most threads on any machine idle most of the time

text: I think there is some much lower fruit to be had by using a dedicated machine, fallacy of premature optimisation

elements.text: I think there is some much lower fruit to be had by using a dedicated machine, fallacy of premature optimisation

text: I would like to avoid busy loops that is for sure. My background is mostly C++ stuff in comms for hardware (stuff like CAN and serial port connections) so when it comes to socket coding I try to stick to blocking socket stuff within a designated thread and thread safe queues to read/write. I am sure there are far better ways, but for HTTPS stuff and python users I imagine you are using higher level packages rather than some low level stuff using OpenSSL libraries. I was just wondering what kind of analysis you guys had done on latency. I am moving to this headless deployment on designated server (not sure yet probably AWS) but these things take time when you are essentially migrating to a new language.

elements.text: I would like to avoid busy loops that is for sure. My background is mostly C++ stuff in comms for hardware (stuff like CAN and serial port connections) so when it comes to socket coding I try to stick to blocking socket stuff within a designated thread and thread safe queues to read/write. I am sure there are far better ways, but for HTTPS stuff and python users I imagine you are using higher level packages rather than some low level stuff using OpenSSL libraries. I was just wondering what kind of analysis you guys had done on latency. I am moving to this headless deployment on designated server (not sure yet probably AWS) but these things take time when you are essentially migrating to a new language.

text: I don't use Python for latency sensitive strategies. And yes, I know my way around the OpenSSL source code :wink:

text: For tracking which strategy places which orders in flumine, should I add my own LoggingControl and post to an API on CLEARED_ORDERS event?

elements.text: For tracking which strategy places which orders in flumine, should I add my own LoggingControl and post to an API on CLEARED_ORDERS event?

text: ORDER on a new order, CLEARED_ORDERS when the market is closed and CLEARED_ORDERS_META for the flumine order object on cleared status if you want to record extra data e.g. seconds to match

elements.text: ORDER on a new order, CLEARED_ORDERS when the market is closed and CLEARED_ORDERS_META for the flumine order object on cleared status if you want to record extra data e.g. seconds to match

text: So I log to an API on the ORDER (post) and then update (patch) on the CLEARED_ORDERS / META the price matched / size / status etc. once the market has closed
